Hmm … hard to give a blanket answer bc every situation is different. But typically, the more senior you get, the less you “own” in terms of execution. 

I’d expect a head of content to be accountable, not responsible, for various things such as the blog or YouTube. When you say “own,” are your talking accountability or responsibility?

text:
More context: I’m a marketing director but you could also view my role as a senior head of content. I do very little execution these days, but I’m accountable for all work completed on my team … then ownership (responsibility) funnels down to the manager of each creative function (editorial, video, design, digital learning), and further to the ICs in each creative function. 

The way you describe it it sounds like you’re a leader but you have equal responsibility for the work done?

text:
Hi <@U027RNU0A69>! Thank you so much for your reply :heart:

When I say “own” I mean that person is responsible for various things to successfully manage the content type they’re assigned to (youtube lead is responsible for hiring video creators, content created, publishing schedule, etc).

Where I feel confused is shouldn’t someone in a role like mine be accountable for all content as a whole (and not just blog)?

When I’ve brought this up to the growth person everyone involved in content reports to I’m told everyone needs to be laser-focused on 1 thing, including me. Meanwhile he’s doing 500 things. I think he is scared of giving up control.

I understand focus is important. But I don’t understand how I’m supposed to lead/guide others this way.

If you were me, is this a red flag or is this a moment where I need to keep insisting our growth lead hands over that responsibility to me?

I’m not sure if I’m being unreasonable. I’ve never worked in a role like this, never worked in a startup that’s gone from 7 to 80 people in such little time, and never worked with someone who leads growth. I’m trying to keep an open mind while also figuring out how/when to be assertive.

text: Sounds like you’re in a content marketing manager role with a head of content title. Maybe he’s unclear on content titles and hierarchy? I would probably ask a lot of questions to understand why you have a leadership title but an IC role in terms of job responsibilities. Yes, a head of content might be a player/coach in a small startup like yours … but it should definitely be more broad in terms of setting strategy, assigning work, coaching players, pulling metrics, making decisions, running meetings, managing workload/resourcing, finding ways to make the team work more effectively or efficiently etc.
